results.title: Self Control
results.description: A quality of mastering one’s impulses and responses through restraint.

results.title: Self Erasure
results.description: A craving to end suffering through erasure of current experience or identity, e.g. “This self is unbearable; I want out.”

results.title: Self Making
results.description: Spiritual or worldly striving to “be someone,” the “I must become something” energy
synonyms: romanticizing some better self or future state

results.title: Recognition of not Self
results.description: Seeing that no phenomenon can rightly be taken as “I” or “mine.” It reveals the impersonal, dependently arisen nature of all experience, undermining conceit and attachment to identity.
synonyms: perception of not being suitable to identify with
realization of being subject to change
recognition of alteration and changing nature

results.title: Boastfulness
results.description: A puffed-up self-display that advertises one's virtues, attainments, or status to win admiration. It springs from conceit and the craving for recognition, crowding out humility and genuine connection.

results.title: Personal existence
results.description: The view that there is a real self within or a substantial reality outside. This mistaken grasp of self and world sustains attachment, conceit, and the cycle of suffering.

results.title: Attabyābādha sutta - Self-Infliction of Harm
results.description: The Buddha explains how bodily, verbal, and mental misconduct lead to self-infliction of harm.
results.contentSnippet: “Bhikkhus, these three qualities lead to <mark class="bg-yellow-100 dark:bg-yellow-900 px-1 rounded">self</mark>-infliction of harm, to the harm of others, and to the harm of both. What are these thre

results.title: Conceit
results.description: Self-view expressed as comparison—seeing oneself as superior, inferior, or equal; the persistent “I am” conceit (asmimāna) that underlies identification and fuels rebirth

results.title: Unassuming
results.description: A gentle, low-profile way of speaking and acting that avoids drawing attention to oneself; restrained in self-display, giving space to others, and simple in manner.

results.title: Humility
results.description: An honest, even-toned self-appraisal that stays open to feedback, honors others, and neither inflates nor denies one’s real abilities; it supports learning, concord, and restraint.

results.title: Attarakkhita sutta - Self-Protection
results.description: Even if protected by an entire army, one who engages in misconduct is unprotected. But one who engages in good conduct protects themselves, even without external protection.

results.title: Anattanibbānasappāya sutta - Not-self As Suitable For Realizing Nibbāna
results.description: The way of practice suitable for realizing Nibbāna is to see the six sense bases and their objects as not-self.

results.title: Anattalakkhaṇa sutta - Characteristic of Being Not-self
results.description: After examining the impermanence, unsatisfactoriness, and the changing nature of the five aggregates, the Buddha teaches how to see them with proper wisdom, as not being suitable to identify with.

results.title: Attadaṇḍa sutta - Arming Oneself

results.title: Suññataloka sutta - Empty Is The World
results.description: The world is empty of self and what belongs to a self.
results.contentSnippet: The eye, Ānanda, is empty of <mark class="bg-yellow-100 dark:bg-yellow-900 px-1 rounded">self</mark> and of what belongs to a <mark class="bg-yellow-100 dark:bg-yellow-900 px-1 rounded">self</mark>. |

results.title: Udāyī sutta - With Udāyī
results.description: The venerable Udāyī asks the venerable Ānanda about how to see the not-self nature of consciousness.

results.title: Sīlasampadādi suttapañcaka - Five Discourses Beginning With Accomplishment in Virtue
results.description: The Buddha explains the importance of accomplishment in virtue, aspiration, self-development, view, and diligence in the development and cultivation of the noble eightfold path.

results.title: Anicca sutta - Impermanence
results.description: The Buddha describes on the impermanent, stressful and not-self nature of the five aggregates of form, feeling, perception, formations and consciousness.
